close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection (fields: daemon, connection_timeout_ms, suspended, last_activity)
struct MHD_Daemon (fields: worker_pool, connection_timeout_ms, normal_timeout_head, normal_timeout_tail, cleanup_connection_mutex)
__builtin_unreachable (builtin) — to see whether it can be emitted unconditionally
explanation: To determine whether any part of MHD_update_last_activity_ is statically unreachable you must know: the shapes and relevant fields of the two involved structs (MHD_Connection and MHD_Daemon) because the function branches on their fields (connection_timeout_ms, suspended, daemon->connection_timeout_ms, daemon->worker_pool, and the list head/tail and mutex used for the timeout DLL); the definition of MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ because it controls an early return and could be a compile-time constant or macro that makes later code unreachable; the definition/expansion of mhd_assert (and whether it emits __builtin_unreachable) and the builtin __builtin_unreachable itself because an assert macro that expands into an unconditional call to __builtin_unreachable would create unreachable code paths; the build-time preprocessor flags (MHD_USE_THREADS, MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, MHD_USE_W32_THREADS) because they enable/disable blocks and thus affect which statements are present in the compiled code; MHD_monotonic_msec_counter for completeness (called in the function) to verify it does not affect reachability via side effects or macros; the mutex lock/unlock helpers because they are conditionally present and might be macros that change control flow; and XDLL_remove/XDLL_insert because they are the operations performed at the end of the function (they could be macros/functions that expand differently under some configs). Each of these symbols can change which statements remain in the compiled code or introduce unconditional termination, so they are required to judge whether any code in MHD_update_last_activity_ is unreachable (MISRA: no unreachable code).
